Cell.Data: Anything between straight brackets - i.e. [ ] - is a formatting tag. Do not change these tags and keep them in the same relative position in the text. Anything between curly brackets - i.e. { } - is a place where text or numbers will be inserted by the game. Do not change the tag, but feel free to change its position in the text to suit the localized text.

In the text below, text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
as in: your ralation with playerX is ….
as in: your ralation with playerX is ….

as in: your ralation with playerX is ….

Shown as a status, e.g. morale: BEST

Shows the name of an alignment and it's effects on the costs in the shop
Shows the name of an alignment and it's effects on the costs in the shop
Shows the name of an alignment and it's effects on the costs in the shop
Shows the name of an alignment and it's effects on the costs in the shop
Shows the name of an alignment and it's effects on the costs in the shop

Unit Morale is increased by 100 due to high Popular Support
Unit Morale is increased by 200 due to high Popular Support
Unit Morale is increased by 300 due to high Popular Support
Unit Morale is reduced by 100 due to low Popular Support
Unit Morale is reduced by 200 due to low Popular Support
Unit Morale is reduced by 300 due to low Popular Support
Unit Morale is increased by 100 due to your race relations with this unit.
Unit Morale is increased by 200 due to your race relations with this unit.
Unit Morale is decreased by 200 due to your race relations with this unit.
Unit Morale is decreased by 400 due to your race relations with this unit.
Unit Morale is decreased by 600 due to your race relations with this unit.

{STR_raceName} is the name of the race which is derived from the Species_NAME.xml files, STR_Standing is one of the below standings, found as RACERELATIONSTANDING. E.G. Vanguard race relation: 100 (Accepted)
Colonies owned by you: {INT_numColonies} ({INT_numPopulation}[population/])[br/]Units owned by you: {INT_numUnits}[br/]
Tooltip breakdown shown as number of colonies owned by the player and the number of of population in those cities, as well as the number of units of that race.
[xpCol]Racial units gain 200 Morale[br/]Racial colonies gain 6 Happiness[br/]75% Influence and Energy cost reduction for race events[br/]+200 opinion from players of that race[/xpCol]
Breakdown of effects for the race relation, shown in tooltips and dialogs.
[xpCol]Racial units gain 100 Morale[br/]Racial colonies gain 4 Happiness[br/]50% Influence and Energy cost reduction for race events[br/]+100 opinion from players of that race[/xpCol]
Breakdown of effects for the race relation, shown in tooltips and dialogs.
[xpCol]Racial colonies gain 2 Happiness[br/]25% Influence and Energy cost reduction for race events[br/]+50 opinion from players of that race[/xpCol]
Breakdown of effects for the race relation, shown in tooltips and dialogs.
[fireCol]Racial units lose 200 Morale[br/]Racial colonies lose 3 Happiness[br/]50% Influence and Energy cost increase for race events[br/]1[casusBelli/] from players of that race[/fireCol]
Breakdown of effects for the race relation, shown in tooltips and dialogs.
[fireCol]Racial units lose 400 Morale[br/]Racial colonies lose 6 Happiness[br/]100% Influence and Energy cost increase for race events[br/]3[casusBelli/] from players of that race[/fireCol]
Breakdown of effects for the race relation, shown in tooltips and dialogs.
[fireCol]Racial units lose 600 Morale[br/]Racial colonies lose 9 Happiness[br/]Race events that cost Influence or Energy are no longer available[br/]5[casusBelli/] from players of that race[/fireCol]
Breakdown of effects for the race relation, shown in tooltips and dialogs.

{STR_raceName} units: {STR_unitNow} (was {STR_unitPrev})[br/]{STR_raceName} colonies: {STR_cityNow} (was {STR_cityPrev})[br/]{STR_raceName} event costs: {STR_eventNow} (was {STR_eventPrev})[br/]{STR_raceName} players opinion: {STR_playerNow} (was {STR_playerPrev})[br/]{STR_raceName} players Casus Belli: {STR_cbNow} [casusBelli/] (was {STR_cbPrev} [casusBelli/])
Shows how the effects of the the previous relation compare to the current effects.
Shown as a single button option, to insult another player
Insult the other player. This will grant them 3 [casusBelli/] against you.
Shown as a single button option, to compliment another player
Compliment the other player. This will improve their opinion of you by 100 [opinion6/].

Shown as a header to a panel. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
This trade is a gift; you receive no items in return.
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface
[grey]You already sent a gift this turn and will not receive a reputation bonus[/grey]
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface
The opinion the opposing player has of you increases by 1 [opinion6/] for each 10 points of value in your gift.
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface
Send a trade offer. The opposing player has one turn to respond to your trade, after which it will automatically be declined. You cannot change or retract your trade offer once it has been sent.
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface
Accept the trade offer. All items and treaties will instantly be transferred.
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface

Send a demand. You request items, but offer nothing to the other player. The opponent may be less likely to accept your trade if nothing is offered in return. You cannot change or retract your trade offer once it has been sent.
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface

Send a counter offer. This will remove the current trade offer and replace it with your counter offer. You cannot change or retract your trade offer once it has been sent. This action does not cause any opinion penalties.
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface
Decline the trade offer. This will remove the trade deal.
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface
This is a one-way demand. This trade will instantly resolve without the opposing player's consent.
Shown as a tooltip in the trading interface

Shown as an item in a list. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Shown as status of the trade below the above STATE_SENT title. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Shown as status of the trade below the above STATE_SENT title. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Shown as status of the trade below the above STATE_SENT title. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Shown as status of the trade below the above STATE_SENT title. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Trade details unavailable; this trade happened too long ago and its records have been lost.
Shown in a tooltip when the trade history is unavailable for a specific trade.
Deal as in trade offer, where good indicates a profitable trade deal which is good for the person viewing the trade, e.g. a very good trade deal
Deal as in trade offer, where good indicates a profitable trade deal which is good for the person viewing the trade, e.g. a very good trade deal
Deal as in trade offer, where good indicates a profitable trade deal which is good for the person viewing the trade, e.g. a very good trade deal
Deal as in trade offer, where good indicates a profitable trade deal which is good for the person viewing the trade, e.g. a very good trade deal
Deal as in trade offer, where good indicates a profitable trade deal which is good for the person viewing the trade, e.g. a very good trade deal
Shown as header for a pop-up
Declare war on {STR_leaderName}. Without any Casus Belli, your reputation and Popular Support will suffer heavily, whereas your enemy's Popular Support will increase.

Shown as caption in a pop-up when declaring war on another player without any Casus Belli Points. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Shown as header for a pop-up
Declare war on {STR_leaderName}. This action will reduce your reputation. Due to your Casus Belli on {STR_leaderName}, both your Popular Support and that of the enemy will increase.

Shown as caption in a pop-up when declaring war on another player with Casus Belli Points. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Declare war on {STR_factionName}. This action will reduce your reputation. [br/][br/]The {STR_factionName} will send out invasion forces to attack your colonies for the duration of the war.
Shown as caption when declaring war on a faction. For example: "Declare war on the Growth…"
Shown as header for a pop-up
Are you sure you want to decline this demand? Ignoring the demand will anger the faction. {STR_factionName} will declare war if you decline their demand.
Shown as caption in a pop-up, {STR_factionName} refers to the name of a faction of non-playable characters
THIS TEXT IS SENT OUT FOR RELOCALIZATION (19/06)
Increasing your diplomatic state with this player means they will be able to call you into war with other players should the need arise:[br/]{STR_playerNames}
Is always followed by a breakdown of effects, e.g. "Declaring war now means +100 points, -250 points".
Are you sure you want to denounce this player?
Shown as title to a pop-up

Denouncing this player will affect them and any other players who know both of you. You can either warn or denounce a player only once for each individual Casus Belli that you currently hold against them.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Are you sure you want to falsely denounce this player?
Shown as title to a pop-up

Denouncing this player will affect them and any other players who know both of you. You can denounce a player only once for each individual fabricated Casus Belli that you currently hold against them.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

You already warned or denounced using this type of Casus Belli; you can only use each type once. Once a war starts between you and the other player, this type is reset and becomes available for denouncements and warnings again.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
There are no other commanders on this planet; denouncing is not effective.
Used to explain that denouncing the player is only effective if there are any other players (alive) in the current game.
Insufficient influence to execute this action.
Shown as a title to a pop-up
You have insufficient influence to execute this action. You can earn more influence through your HQ Colony and by completing quests.
Are you sure you want to warn this player?
Shown as a title to a pop-up

This warning is private between you and the target player. They will be made aware that their previous action may have consequences. You can either warn or denounce a player only once for each individual Casus Belli that you currently hold against them.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Resource treaties can only be broken by declaring war or waiting for it to expire over time. Diplomatic treaties are broken by lowering the diplomatic state. When a treaty breaks/expires, any other treaty made in the same trade deal also expires.
Shown as a title to a pop-up
Used as name for calling people to war, is also shown on buttons.
{STR_requestPlayer} can accept your call to war

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
{STR_requestPlayer} cannot accept your call to war

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
You do not share a defensive pact or alliance with {STR_requestPlayer}

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
You have a queued diplomatic state with {STR_requestPlayer}

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
{STR_requestPlayer} has a queued diplomatic state with {STR_targetPlayer}

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
You have a queued diplomatic state with {STR_targetPlayer}

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
{STR_requestPlayer} already has a call to war against {STR_targetPlayer}

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

{STR_targetPlayer} did not start the war; you can only call players with whom you share a defensive pact into a defensive war. If you forge an alliance with {STR_requestPlayer}, you'll be able to call {STR_requestPlayer} into any type of war.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
You are not at war with {STR_targetPlayer}

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
{STR_requestPlayer} is in a fixed relation with {STR_targetPlayer} and cannot accept your call

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
{STR_requestPlayer} is recuperating and cannot respond to your call

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
{STR_requestPlayer} is defeated and cannot respond to your call

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
You are fighting an aggressive war against {STR_targetPlayer}. You cannot call your overlord, {STR_requestPlayer}, into this war.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
{STR_requestPlayer} is a vassal of {STR_targetPlayer} and cannot declare war

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Are you sure you want to call this ally into war?

{STR_allyName} will be able to either accept or decline your request to join your war with {STR_opponentName}. If they accept, they will declare war on {STR_opponentName}. However, if they decline your call to war, {STR_allyName} will exit your alliance with them and will revert to a non-aggression pact. The called player has up to 3 turns to respond.

This text mentions multiple people that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
{STR_allyName} must accept your request to join your war with {STR_opponentName}.

This text mentions multiple people that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

{STR_allyName} will be able to either accept or decline your request to join your war with {STR_opponentName}. If they accept, they will declare war on {STR_opponentName}. However, your overlord may freely decline your call to war. The called player has up to 3 turns to respond.

This text mentions multiple people that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Your ally, {STR_allyName}, has called for you to aid them in their war against {STR_enemyName}. Accepting this request will declare war on {STR_enemyName}. Declining this call to war will break your alliance with {STR_allyName}, also yielding considerable opinion penalties.

This text mentions multiple people that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Your vassal, {STR_allyName}, has called for you to aid them in their war against {STR_enemyName}. Accepting this request will declare war on {STR_enemyName}. Since you are the overlord of {STR_allyName}, declining this call to war only yields an opinion penalty.

This text mentions multiple people that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Your overlord, {STR_allyName}, has called upon you for aid in their war against {STR_enemyName}. Accepting this request will declare war on {STR_enemyName}. Because you are a vassal of {STR_allyName}, you cannot decline their call to war.

This text mentions multiple people that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Accepting will declare war on the target player, you receive an additional {INT_cbPoints}[casusBelli/] for aiding your ally.
Tooltip. {INT_cbPoints} is a number that will be filled out by the game
Declining will upset the other player, but will not break the relation because you are their overlord.
Declining will break the relationship and revert back to a non-aggression pact, yielding a -100 [opinion0/] opinion penalty as well as reputation penalties for lowering your diplomatic state.
Are you sure you want to decline this call to war?
Shown as a header in a pop-up window
Declining will cause your relationship to revert to a non-aggression pact. Furthermore, the opinion the other player has of you drops by -100 [opinion0/].
Declining causes the opinion the other player has of you to drop by -100 [opinion0/].
Shown as a button caption for when responding to a call to war, for example "Call to war against Bob". This means someone else called you to war against Bob.
Are you sure you want to insult this player?
Shown as a header in a pop-up window
Insulting another player costs 10 [influence/] and will grant the other player 3 [casusBelli/] against you.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Are you sure you want to compliment this player?
Shown as a header in a pop-up window
Complimenting the other player costs 10 [influence/] and will improve their opinion of you by 100 [opinion6/].

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
You already influenced this player this turn.
Shown as a header in a pop-up window
You already influenced this player recently, you can influence them again in {INT_turns}[turn/].
Shown as a header in a pop-up window
Shown as a status next to casus belli names, for example "Name did something horrible (Fabricated)"
Warn or denounce {STR_playerName} about their actions

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
You can either warn or denounce a player only once for each individual Casus Belli that you currently hold against them. Warning is a private message, whereas denouncing is a public proclamation.
You currently have no Casus Belli against this player to use to warn or denounce them.
You already warned or denounced this player this turn.
Players that know both you and {STR_leaderName} will receive an opinion penalty on {STR_leaderName}:

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Is always followed by a number
Is followed by the name of the Casus Belli being used to denounce the other player.
There is already a pending trade offer.
You've recently met this player, wait {INT_turns}[turn/] before they will accept a new diplomatic state.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
The player will not trade away this sector because it will disconnect one or multiple sectors from their colony.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
The player has already recently agreed to a new diplomatic state, wait {INT_turns}[turn/] before offering a new diplomatic state.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
The player has already recently agreed to a treaty, wait {INT_turns}[turn/] before offering another treaty.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
The player will not trade away this colony unless in a truce negotiation.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
The player has already recently given you a sector, wait {INT_turns}[turn/] before offering another sector.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
The player is already giving you resources per turn and will not do so again.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
This player is not ready to forget their dislikes, wait {INT_turns}[turn/] before trying to overcome the dislikes they have. This duration is reset if either player declares war on the other.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
The player doesn't like you enough to accept a better diplomatic state.
Show in a tooltip to explain why another player will not accept a trade option
You cannot perform this action while your commander is recuperating.
You cannot perform this action while the other commander is recuperating.
You cannot perform this action because your diplomatic relationship with the other player is fixed.
You cannot perform this action while you are negotiating a truce with the other player.
You cannot perform this action while there is a pending diplomatic state change between you and the other player.
You cannot perform this action while you are at war with the other player.
You cannot perform this action while you are a vassal of the other player.
Description for the player having a certain reputation. This is shown both to the player but also to other players as third parties.

Description for the player having a certain reputation. This is shown both to the player but also to other players as third parties.

People tend to have an indifferent opinion.
Description for the player having a certain reputation. This is shown both to the player but also to other players as third parties.
A neutral reputation has no substantial effect on other players. Once the reputation increases or decreases to a different level, player opinions and Dwelling shop costs will change.
Breakdown of the effects for a specific reputation state.
Seen by other players as mostly dependable and cooperative.
Description for the player having a certain reputation. This is shown both to the player but also to other players as third parties.
[xpCol]+50[largeTab/]Opinion from other reputable players[/xpCol][br/][fireCol]-50[largeTab/]Opinion of disreputable players[/fireCol]
Breakdown of the effects for a specific reputation state.
Widely respected by other players for moral actions.
Description for the player having a certain reputation. This is shown both to the player but also to other players as third parties.
[xpCol]+50[largeTab/]Opinion from other reputable players[/xpCol][br/][fireCol]-50[largeTab/]Opinion of disreputable players[/fireCol]
Breakdown of the effects for a specific reputation state.
Held in the highest esteem among other honorable players.
Description for the player having a certain reputation. This is shown both to the player but also to other players as third parties.
Breakdown of the effects for a specific reputation state.
Name of a diplomatic state, is used as a title, but can also be used in breakdowns inserted into scentences like "Current diplomatic state: WAR".
Name of a diplomatic state, is used as a title, but can also be used in breakdowns inserted into scentences like "Current diplomatic state: WAR".

Name of a diplomatic state, is used as a title, but can also be used in breakdowns inserted into scentences like "Current diplomatic state: WAR".
Name of a diplomatic state, is used as a title, but can also be used in breakdowns inserted into scentences like "Current diplomatic state: WAR".
While at war, players can attack each other, claim sectors and perform operations at will.

While in a neutral state, the players' relationship can change positively or negatively. The path to war lies open, or more peaceful options can be pursued, such as the Non-Aggression Pact, Defensive Pact, and eventually an Alliance.
Both players agree to avoid aggressive action, and cannot directly attack each other without first breaking this pact.
Both players agree to a defensive pact in which they can call upon each other for help when fighting a defensive war, becoming allies in battle.
The strongest bond two players can share; while in an alliance, allied victories are enabled, and players can call upon each other for aid in wars.
The diplomatic state is unknown as the players have not yet met each other.
Shown in a sentence behind the diplomatic state when the diplomatic state is about to change automatically during the next turn. E.g. "Diplomatic state: Alliance (change pending)"
The relation has a pending change which will change the diplomatic state to {STR_state} on the next turn.

Explains to the player that there is a pending diplomatic state change that will change the state of the relation to {STR_state}. STR_State is filled out by one of the DIPLOMATIC_STATE entries, for example Alliance.
This is shown in the interface as a status, it reflects how your population views you as their leader.

[largeIndent]No effects and no penalties. You will start receiving bonuses if you increase your Popular Support level, or penalties if your Popular Support level drops any further.[/largeIndent]
Breakdown of having a specific popular support status
Breakdown of having a specific popular support status
Breakdown of having a specific popular support status
Breakdown of having a specific popular support status

The popular support of your empire and your people, which affects Unit Upkeep, Unit Production Cost and the Happiness of your colonists.[br/]It is influenced by the wars you enter and how justified they are perceived to be.
Name of a modifier, shown in breakdowns/lists
Name of a modifier, shown in breakdowns/lists
Name of a modifier, shown in breakdowns/lists
Name of a modifier, shown in breakdowns/lists
Name of a modifier, shown in breakdowns/lists
Casus Belli (plural) are causes for war or justification to go to war. This is an in-game mechanic which may be mentioned in other texts by name.

Casus Belli represent your justifications for starting a war. As other players offend you, your Casus Belli against them will rise. The higher your Casus Belli number, the more popular going to war will be, and the less our reputation will suffer.
Shown at the end of a casus belli name when a player cannot get any more casus belli points for a specific type. For example: "6 x PLAYERNAME trespassed in my domain (Cap reached)"
Shown in a tooltip as: "Casus Belli against you: Minor (3 points)"
Title for having 0 Casus Belli points
With no justification, war would be deeply unpopular.
Tooltip description of a Casus Belli level
Title for having some Casus Belli points
War is possible, but our reputation would still suffer.
Tooltip description of a Casus Belli level
Title for having more Casus Belli points
War would be popular, and we would only lose a moderate amount of reputation.
Tooltip description of a Casus Belli level
Title for having the maximum amount of Casus Belli points
The people demand war, and no one would think badly of us for starting one.
Tooltip description of a Casus Belli level
Used as an item in lists

This player is your vassal. They have sworn allegiance to your cause and must come to your aid when called to war. Neither you nor the vassal can attack each other unless you decide to break this pact. You will gain an additional {INT_energy}% energy and {INT_research}% research per turn based on the income of your vassal.

Tooltip description for vassal players. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Edit: only the overlord can break the pact
Used as an item in lists
This player is your sworn overlord. Their mercy is your survival. You must come to the aid of your overlord when called to war. Only your overlord can decide to break this pact.

Tooltip description for overlord players. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Edit: only the overlord can break the pact
Description in the resource income breakdowns for resource income gained from vassal players.
Title for the popular support mechanic. Shown as Popular Support: STATUS

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Do you want to build in this claimed sector?

This sector has already been [hyperlink,000003A600000329]claimed[/hyperlink]. Building here causes other commanders to gain a Casus Belli (4[casusBelli/] points) against you, making it easier for them to declare war on you. Independent factions will make demands if you ignore their claims.[br/][br/]The following commanders and factions have claimed this sector:
Pop-up description for wanting to build on a claimed location. Will be followed by a list of players/factions who have already laid claim on the location.
Are you sure you want to build here?
Do you want to enter this claimed structure?

This sector has already been [hyperlink,000003A600000329]claimed[/hyperlink]. Capturing it causes other commanders to gain a Casus Belli (4[casusBelli/] points) against you, making it easier for them to declare war on you. Independent factions may demand compensation for ignoring their claims[br/][br/]The following commanders and factions have claimed this sector:

Pop-up description for wanting to capture a claimed location. Will be followed by a list of players/factions who have already laid claim on the location. This tooltip is similar to the previous tooltip
Are you sure you want to enter this structure?
Name of a relation standing, may also be inserted into texts like "StandingName - Effect"
Name of a relation standing, may also be inserted into texts like "StandingName - Effect"
Name of a relation standing, may also be inserted into texts like "StandingName - Effect"

Name of a relation standing, may also be inserted into texts like "StandingName - Effect"
Are you sure you want to start coordinating this ally?

Requesting to coordinate {STR_allyName} costs {INT_influenceCost}[influence/] and motivates them to focus on targets of your choosing. {STR_allyName} will try to follow your war coordination requests for up to {INT_turns}[turn/], though they may abort or decline before that time runs out. After that time they will abort any current mission and the coordination automatically ends.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Are you sure you want to abort your request?
Are you sure you want to abort this war coordination request? This will immediately abort the action without refunding any spent [influence/] points!

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Opens the pronouncement sub-options. These enable you to make statements or declarations to affect your relationship with the opposing player.
Treaty Title, shown in lists and is inserted into strings like "Player Name - Opened borders"
Open borders allow the other player to freely move their units through another player's domain without trespassing.
Treaty Title, shown in lists and is inserted into strings like "Player Name - Opened borders"
Sharing vision grants vision of all owned units, structures and sectors to the other player.
Treaty Title, shown in lists and is inserted into strings like "Player Name - Opened borders"

This mutual treaty provides better defense against all operations for both players, whilst lowering each player's defense against operations they deploy on each other. Both players' secret tech will be revealed, as well as those of third parties that have already been revealed.
Treaty Title, shown in lists and is inserted into strings like "Player Name - Opened borders"
With this mutual treaty, the commanders vow to (temporarily) not attack each other. Commanders can still declare war, but suffer an additional reputation penalty.
Treaty Title, shown in lists and is inserted into strings like "Player Name - Opened borders"
This treaty allows the commander to build on sectors claimed by the other without suffering any penalties.
Shown in tooltips below the description of the treaty and is followed by a list of treaty names.
You may not enter an alliance with this player while you are running the Planetary Unification Protocol. Either you or the other player must stop the Protocol before you continue.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.
Unit Morale is increased by 400 because you integrated the faction this unit originates from.
Unit Morale is increased by 200 because you share a friendship with the faction this unit originates from.
Unit Morale is increased by 100 because you are at peace with the faction this unit originates from.
Unit Morale is decreased by 400 because you are at war with the faction this unit originates from.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

This value reflects the opinion one player has of another, and is affected by their shared diplomatic state, reputations and actions (represented as modifiers). The value ranges between [fireCol]{INT_min}[/fireCol] (lowest opinion) and [xpCol]{INT_max}[/xpCol] (highest opinion).
Reflects the opinion {STR_leaderName}'s empire has towards our empire. The higher the relation value the more likely they are to trade with us or accept our demands.

This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

Shown as title to a message. This text refers to a person that can either be male or female. If relevant for translation, please use the ‘localized string’ column for the male text and the ‘alternative localized string’ column for the female text.

{STR_leaderName} has captured {STR_sectorName}. Because of your claims on this sector, you have gained a Casus Belli (4[casusBelli/] points) on {STR_leaderName}, allowing you to declare war on them with Popular Support.
[fireCol]Due to ongoing effects, you cannot currently make use of your Casus Belli.[/fireCol]
Shown as status effect below the above pop-up caption
Due to ongoing effects, you are currently unaffected by Popular Support penalties for declaring war without Casus Belli.
Shown as status effect below the above pop-up caption
Button caption for requesting an ally to attack another player
Button caption for requesting an ally to attack a player, {STR_leaderName} is replaced with the name of a player.
Shown as status in a tooltip
Shown as status in a tooltip
Button caption for telling your ally to cancel their attack
Button caption for revealing the target location for the attack on the map.
Button caption for exiting the window without changing the state of the attack request.
Button caption for changing the target of the call to arms
I need to consider your request. Let me get back to you on that!
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player is still considering the request
I think I can do this. {INT_turnsUntilTarget} turns until I reach the target!
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player starts with the attack
I'm on my way. I estimate it will take me {INT_turnsUntilTarget} turns to reach my target!
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player is currently traveling to the location
This will take me some time, but I'm on my way. It will take me roughly {INT_turnsUntilTarget} turns to reach the target!
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player is still traveling to the location
This is going to take longer than expected. It will take {INT_turnsUntilTarget} turns before I reach the target!
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player is still traveling to the location but has been delayed
Almost there! {INT_turnsUntilTarget} turns to reach the target!
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player is about to reach the target
My attention is needed elsewhere at the moment, but I'll try to get back to our target soon!
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player has paused the attack temporarily
I've reached the target, my army is guarding the location!
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player cancels the attack
This is simply too much. I can't do it...
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player cancels the attack
Due to our current standing, I will no longer be able to comply with your requests.
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player cancels the attack because their relation with the requesting player has degraded
Abort! I'm not going to be able to do this for you.
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player aborts the attack because they cannot reach the target
I can't do this for you, not right now at least.
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player declines the request
Threat eliminated, scanning perimeter for more hostiles.
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player has performed the attack
I've fulfilled my duties and trust my services were satisfactory.
Message response from the other player when asking the current status of the attack request. - The player has performed the attack
Select a structure that can be attacked or defended
Structures you are both at war with can be attacked. Structures belonging to players with whom {STR_leaderName} shares at least a defensive pact with can be defended (including their own structures).
Button caption when sending a positive first meeting message to the other player.
Button caption for not sending any message and ignoring their first contact.
Button caption when sending a negative first meet message to the other player.
Close diplomacy screen and visit this dwelling
You haven't discovered this dwelling yet.
Tooltip when a dwelling has not been discovered yet.
Results from an operation, shown in a list breakdown.
[fireCol]This operation cannot be used in fixed teams[/fireCol]
Shown in tooltips when operations cannot be used in the fixed teams game mode.
A bonus gained from Skilled Diplomat perk. Please translate consistently.
A bonus gained from Martial Tradition perk. Please translate consistently.
Negotiate with this commander to improve relations.
Send a compliment or negotiate a trade to avoid relations getting worse.
This commander may declare war soon, improve the relation to try to avoid war.
Negotiate a truce with this commander to improve relations.
Actively engage in diplomacy to maintain relations.
Avoid generating Casus Belli for this commander if you want to maintain positive relations.
A new treaty was formed. Review treaties in the treaties list to the right.
You are now at war with this commander! Most diplomatic interactions are disabled until a truce is formed.
The negotiation failed. The same negotiation can be proposed in 3 turns.

{STR_color1Open}This commander’s opinion of you has changed by {INT_value1} due to their personality trait.{STR_color1Close}
{STR_color1Open}This commander’s opinion of you has changed by {INT_value1}.{STR_color1Close}[br/]{STR_color2Open} You have gained {INT_value2} Casus Belli on this commander.{STR_color2Close}
